results.title: Britain's new resources
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Is Britain”.
A brief study of the uses to which Britain is putting her limited natural resources; the harvesting, scientific drying, and storing of short grass for feeding cattle all the year round; the planting of forests and cutting of timber; harnessing of hydro-electric power; soap manufacture without fats; the use of seaweed in the manufacture of many products; production of magnesium from the waters of the North Sea.

results.title: Bristol: British city
results.creator_credit: Alexander Shaw, World Wide Pictures and Mary Francis
results.brief_description: The people of Bristol tell of their city, long since called the Maritime Capital of the West of England; a city with whose history many pioneers, adventurers and navigators, and many great moral and spiritual leaders have been associated. With its bustling life and half a million citizens, the city’s efficiency is still symbolised by the old phrase “shipshape and Bristol fashion”.

results.title: Bristol fashion
results.creator_credit: Terry Ashwood, Associated British-Pathe and Eric Fullilove
results.brief_description: The history and development of the Port of Bristol - the only major municipally owned port in Britain. Illustrates the facilities available in the city docks and at Avonmouth and Portishead, and discusses plans for the expansion of dock services. Sequences on the history of architecture of Bristol are interwoven.

results.title: Brisbane: city in the sun
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson, Australian National Film Board and Hugh McInnes
results.brief_description: This film illustrates the pattern of life in Brisbane, Queensland. Aspects such as commerce, tourist appeal and the social pastimes of locals and tourists are depicted. Includes views of the races, the beach and Brisbane River. Camera: Edward Cranstone Sound: Donald Kennedy Music: Don Andrews

results.title: Brisbane 1982: the twelfth Commonwealth Games
results.creator_credit: Terence McMahon and Terence McMahon Productions
results.brief_description: Produced as part of Comalco’s sponsorship of the Commonwealth Games to be held in Brisbane in 1982. Includes historic newsreel footage of major performances by Australians in the past Commonwealth Games. Also shows some of Australia’s athletes training for the 1982 Games.

results.title: Bringing Up Baby
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures and Howard Hawks
results.brief_description: Cary Grant is an absent-minded zoology professor who needs one million dollars for his nature museum. Katharine Hepburn, in her first foray into real comedy, is an heiress who is determined to get him the money, and to win his heart. However, first she must get him to drop his fiance, find his dinosaur bone which she has lost, and convince him to look after her pet leopard named Baby. An outstanding, fast-paced comedy and one of Howard Hawk’s most loved films.

results.title: Bringing out the dead
results.creator_credit: Barbara de Fina, Touchstone Pictures, Paramount Pictures, Cappa and Martin Scorsese
results.brief_description: An intense urban drama, set in Hell’s Kitchen and interpreted by many critics as an unofficial sequel to Scorsese’s iconic “Taxi driver”, “Bringing out the dead” examines one man’s crisis of conscience as he battles the furious demons that occupy his soul and the sullied streets where he works as a paramedic. Set in early 1990s, Scorsese evokes a New York awash with filth, human degradation, violence, drug abuse and amorality. Nicolas Cage puts in an incendiary performance as Frank - a man struggling to locate his compassion amid the overwhelming cruelty that rages around him. His (then wife) Patricia Arquette also puts in a fine performance as Mary Burke, the daughter of a patient Frank has brought in. Mary, a virgin/whore figure who similarly rages at the injustices and inequities of life, may save Frank - as he rescues her from drug addiction. In this redemptive tale Frank inches towards salvation - dragging the ghosts of the unsaved with him. Containing evocative religious (particularly Christian) imagery, scriptwriter Paul Schrader (Taxi driver, Raging bull, The Last temptation of Christ) continues his explorations into urban decay, morality, salvation, humanism, spirituality and violence. Adapted from the novel by Joseph Connolly.

results.title: Bringing me home
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Karen Greer and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Mitchell River is the largest unregulated river in Victoria. To Karen Greer, it is her home and ever since childhood, she has navigated the waters and continues tracing the river upstream.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Karen Greer and ACMI

results.title: Bring out a Briton
results.brief_description:
“Form a committee in your district and… Bring Out A Briton”. Chips Rafferty is called upon to promote the Department of Immigration’s campaign to encourage sponsored British migration to Australia.
Launched in 1957, the program urged towns across Australia to form committees to organise employment opportunities and accommodation for incoming British migrants.
